thread.title: Game of the Week: Bel Air, Aberdeen again playing for league supremacy
thread.title_full: Game of the Week: Bel Air, Aberdeen again playing for league supremacy

author: Katherine Dunn
title: Game of the Week: Bel Air, Aberdeen again playing for league supremacy
text:
(Katherine Dunn) 
Their showdown features a clash of styles with the Eagles preferring to spread things out and mix it up on offense while, as Huryk says, Bel Air's style is "four yards and a cloud of dust." 
The Bobcats ran that to perfection in last year's 28-0 Class 3A North regional semifinal over the Eagles. Their steady running game kept the ball out of Aberdeen's hands. Brooks said the Eagles only had the ball twice in the second half. 
"I don't think we ever got the ball in the third quarter," Brooks said. "They like to pound it and it just never ended for us, but that's the type of game they love to play. But we find it frustrating." 
That playoff win by the Bobcats was their first over Aberdeen since 2009. During the regular season, the Eagles kicked a field goal in the final minutes to win. 
The Bobcats, who have a handful of strong running backs, got two touchdowns from Hulse last week in a 17-6 win over C. Milton Wright. 
"When we don't make mistakes, we are methodical about what we do," Huryk said. "When we don't get little yellow hankies, it's four yards, four yards, four yards and that adds up to first downs." 
The Eagles, a younger team than the Bobcats, also have struggled with penalties at times this season. They led 21-20 going into the fourth quarter against Fallston Friday night, thanks to throwing three interceptions that all led to Cougars touchdown. Aberdeen finally pulled away for a 42-28 win with Lyons gaining 225 total yards and scoring a touchdown and Everett adding 165 yards rushing and two touchdowns. 
"We need to do what we like to do, which is run, throw, spread people out a little bit and try to get them away from just packing it in, everybody just grinding, grinding, grinding on you," Brooks said. "So it's going to be a game of styles. Whichever style works is going to win." 
OTHER GAMES TO WATCH 
No. 7 Archbishop Spalding at No. 1 Gilman, Friday, 3:30 p.m. 
Dunbar at No. 12 Mervo, Friday, 6 p.m. 
River Hill at No. 14 Oakland Mills, Friday, 7 p.m. 
Glen Burnie at No. 10 Broadneck, Saturday, 12:45 p.m.
